drug.name: Ibandronate
drug.description: Ibandronate is a nitrogen-containing bisphosphonate in the same class as alendronate and risedronate. Ibandronate inhibits osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. All of the bisphosphonates prevent the breakdown of bone by bone cells called osteoclasts. In persons who are at high risk for osteoporosis, bisphosphonates not only result in increased amounts of bone and bone strength, they also reduce the risk of hip fractures and other bone fractures.

article.citation: Epstein S, Zaidi M: Biological properties and mechanism of action of ibandronate: application to the treatment of osteoporosis. Bone. 2005 Oct;37(4):433-40.

drug.synthesis-reference: Revital Lifshitz-Liron, Thomas Bayer, Judith Aronhime, Michael Pinchasov, "Solid and crystalline ibandronate sodium and processes for preparation thereof." U.S. Patent US20070179119, issued August 02, 2007.
drug.indication: For the treatment and prevention of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women.
drug.pharmacodynamics: Ibandronate is a nitrogen-containing bisphosphonate in the same class as alendronate and risedronate. Ibandronate inhibits osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. All of the bisphosphonates prevent the breakdown of bone by bone cells called osteoclasts. In persons who are at high risk for osteoporosis, bisphosphonates not only result in increased amounts of bone and bone strength, they also reduce the risk of hip fractures and other bone fractures.
drug.mechanism-of-action: The action of ibandronate on bone tissue is based partly on its affinity for hydroxyapatite, which is part of the mineral matrix of bone. Nitrogen-containing bisphosphonates (such as pamidronate, alendronate, risedronate, ibandronate and zoledronate) appear to act as analogues of isoprenoid diphosphate lipids, thereby inhibiting farnesyl pyrophosphate (FPP) synthase, an enzyme in the mevalonate pathway. Inhibition of this enzyme in osteoclasts prevents the biosynthesis of isoprenoid lipids (FPP and GGPP) that are essential for the post-translational farnesylation and geranylgeranylation of small GTPase signalling proteins. This activity inhibits osteoclast activity and reduces bone resorption and turnover. In postmenopausal women, it reduces the elevated rate of bone turnover, leading to, on average, a net gain in bone mass.
drug.toxicity: LD<sub>50</sub> = 811 mg/kg (rat, oral), side effects include bronchitis, pneumonia and urinary tract infections.
drug.metabolism: No evidence of ibandronate being metabolized in humans.
drug.absorption: Poorly absorbed (mean bioavailability following a 2.5 mg oral dose is about 0.6% compared to intravenous dosing). Absorption is impaired by any kind of food or drink other than plain water.
drug.protein-binding: 90.9 to 99.5% over an ibandronate concentration range of 2 to 10 ng/mL
drug.route-of-elimination: Ibandronate is eliminated by renal excretion. Unabsorbed ibandronate is eliminated unchanged in the feces.

classification.description: This compound belongs to the class of organic compounds known as bisphosphonates. These are organic compounds containing two phosphonate groups linked together through a carbon atoms.

packager.name: Vetter Pharma Fertigung GmbH and Co. KG

category.category: Drugs Affecting Bone Structure and Mineralization
Drugs for Treatment of Bone Diseases

atc-code.level: DRUGS AFFECTING BONE STRUCTURE AND MINERALIZATION
DRUGS FOR TREATMENT OF BONE DISEASES
DRUGS AFFECTING BONE STRUCTURE AND MINERALIZATION
DRUGS FOR TREATMENT OF BONE DISEASES

food-interactions.food-interaction: Take on an empty stomach. All foods markedly reduce (up to 90%) ibandronate bioavailabilty. Take with plain water (not mineralized) at least 1 hour before any food. Bioavailability and effect on bone density are both impaired if the patient eats or drinks in less than 1 hour after taking this product. Drink a large glass of water and stay in an upright position for at least 60 minutes after taking this product.

polypeptide.name: Farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase
polypeptide.specific-function: Key enzyme in isoprenoid biosynthesis which catalyzes the formation of farnesyl diphosphate (FPP), a precursor for several classes of essential metabolites including sterols, dolichols, carotenoids, and ubiquinones. FPP also serves as substrate for protein farnesylation and geranylgeranylation. Catalyzes the sequential condensation of isopentenyl pyrophosphate with the allylic pyrophosphates, dimethylallyl pyrophosphate, and then with the resultant geranylpyrophosphate to the ultimate product farnesyl pyrophosphate.
